properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heat event continues through Monday. Inland from Lake Superior, daytime high temperatures near 29 degrees Celsius can be expected. Overnight low temperatures will range from 16 to 18 degrees Celsius. A cold front is expected to move through the area on Tuesday, and although maximum daily temperatures are expected to remain in the upper twenties, Heat Warning criteria is not expected to be met. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-06T23:16:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-06T07:17:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3271280185.2020
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A heat wave is expected this week. A warm and humid air mass over Southern Quebec will persist over the next few days. Beginning Tuesday, temperature will exceed the 30-degree mark during the day and is not expected to drop below 20 degrees at night. Combined values of the temperature and the humidity will give humidex values near 40. These conditions may persist into Friday. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-07T00:25:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-06T08:26:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3408718568.2020
Area: Longueuil - Varennes area, Laval area, Montréal Island area, Châteauguay - La Prairie area, Soulanges area, Vaudreuil area, Saint-Rémi area, Valleyfield - Beauharnois area, Hemmingford area, Huntingdon area, Sorel - Yamaska area, Saint-Hyacinthe - Acton Vale area, Verchères - Beloeil area, Saint-Jean - Marieville area, Lacolle area
